items.title: Inclusive terminology
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Inclusive terminology

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Change the terminology of blacklist to either denylist or blocklist.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
No alternatives.

**Additional context**
Hey bandit team,

I'm from a Microsoft team that runs a static analysis engine that installs, configures, runs, and process results of multiple static analysis tools. We recently released a GitHub action (by GitHub) which includes the ability to run bandit:
https://github.com/marketplace/actions/ossar-action

While reviewing some sample results, the term "blacklist" showed up in a rule message. As you are likely aware, Microsoft and GitHub are moving towards inclusive terminology, and this one is on the list.

Being open source, the first thing I went to do is sync the bandit code, attempt to make the change, and send a PR to request the change. However, as I did so, I quickly realized this may not be a matter of string message resourcing, but the name of an entire, extendable feature within the bandit framework itself. Am I correct in assuming that dependent plugins may also reference and leverage the blacklist feature?

If so, this request (without backwards compatibility) would be a breaking change requiring a major version upgrade of the tool, which I understand is a massive request.

If you could help me understand the impact of such a change and if there would be a way to update this, that would be wonderful.

Bandit is a great tool and we are thankful to have it out there protecting and securing the global developer ecosystem.

Our team is not blocked.

Thanks,
Dave Knise (Microsoft)

items.title: Option to force colors even if not a TTY
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I'm writing a simple Python script that captures the output of a command to print its output only if it failed ([failprint](https://github.com/pawamoy/failprint)). Since I'm using `subprocess.PIPE`, bandit detects that it's not a TTY and disables the colors.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like bandit to provide an option to force the use of colors even if stdout is not a TTY, so I can print them again myself.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I can fake a TTY with [ptyprocess](https://github.com/pexpect/ptyprocess), but
1. I'm not sure it works well on Windows
2. I cannot read stdout and stderr separately

**Additional context**
It's usually a good idea to give control over the colors to the user. For example `grep` and other GNU tools allow that with the `--color` option, which accepts `never`, `auto` and `always`. As you can guess, `auto` corresponds to what you're already doing: disabling colors when not in a TTY.

I'd be happy to open a PR :slightly_smiling_face:

items.title: Importing bandit messes up console output on Windows.
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Importing bandit module changes the formatting on Windows console. This is because in one of the files, Colorama is imported and initialized without being deinitialized.

**To Reproduce**
0. Use Windows
1. Install bandit
2. Install colorama
3. print `'\033[4mHello, World!\033[0m'` before and after importing `bandit`.

**Expected behavior**
One should not be forced to use `Colorama` just because they imported `bandit`.

**Suggested solution**
After the bandit outputting is done, call  :
```python
colorama.deinit()
```

**Bandit version**
Since https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/pull/424, _i.e_ since 1.6.0.

items.title: Ignore virtualenv and __pycache__ directories
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
N/A

**Describe the solution you'd like**
When a project that has made use of virtualenv or tox, there is usually a directory named `.venv`, `.tox` or the like.  As a result when bandit scans this project, it automatically scans all of the virtualenv site-packages.  This can be many many python files that don't need to be scanned.

Similarly, `__pycache__` directories are created by the compiler.  Bandit can also safely ignore those.

Bandit should really attempt to ignore all hidden directories by default.  I suggest a config option of `include_hidden` that defaults to `False`.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative is to default this new config setting to `True`. 

Another alternative is to provide the option in the command line if useful.  How often do people desire to scan the dependencies of a project in the virtualenv directory?

**Additional context**
N/A

items.title: GitPython dropped py2 support again, which breaks bandit's py2.7 support
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Bandit's README says it supports py2, but out of the box no longer does. This is because GitPython is not pinned, nor specifies a version range ([GitPython just made a major version release](https://github.com/gitpython-developers/GitPython/blob/master/doc/source/changes.rst#300---remove-python-2-support) in the last day that officially drops py2 support)

**To Reproduce**
1. create a py2 virtual env (`virtualenv venv`)
2. venv/bin/pip install bandit
3. watch it fail with a message similar to: `GitPython requires Python '>=3.0, !=3.0., !=3.1., !=3.2., !=3.3.' but the running Python is 2.7.15`

**Expected behavior**
I would expect either:
- It be documented in the README that you need to pin the version of GitPython yourself if you want py2 support
- It be documented that py2 is no longer supported (if it gets decided)
- The package to install without errors

**Bandit version**
NOTE: This should be reproducible with any version, but the service I was dealing with uses:
```
bandit==1.4.0
```

**Additional context**
N/A

items.title: hashlib_new_insecure_functions plugin fails to parse dynamic code
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Running this plugin against a hashlib.new invocation that does accept the hashing algo dynamically from an inline function of a variable fails with 
`AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lower'`

**To Reproduce**
minimal repro module `test_hash_new.py`
```
import hashlib

def bandit_fail(algo):
    return hashlib.new(str(algo))
```

Run `bandit >=1.5.0` against it (that's where that check plugin appeared first time)
```
$ bandit test_hash_new.py
...
[tester]        ERROR   Bandit internal error running: hashlib_new on file test_hash_new.py at line 4: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lower'Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                                       
  File "/home/pshchelo/.virtualenvs/bandit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/bandit/core/tester.py", line 64, in run_tests                                                                                                                                                                      
    result = test(context)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
  File "/home/pshchelo/.virtualenvs/bandit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/bandit/plugins/hashlib_new_insecure_functions.py", line 57, in hashlib_new                                                                                                                                         
    if name.lower() in ('md4', 'md5'):
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lower'
...
```
Note that moving `str` out of call to `hashlib.new` solves the issue.

**Expected behavior**
At least no failure/traceback. Possibly the same error emitted but with lower confidence stating something like "Verify that no insecure algos are being passed here".

**Bandit version**
<!--- Paste the output from "bandit --version" between quotes below -->
```
bandit 1.6.0
  python version = 3.6.5 (default, Apr  1 2018, 05:46:30) [GCC 7.3.0]
```
but observed on any bandit 1.5.x too, where this check plugin is already available

**Additional context**
Seems like aftermath of implementing https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/issues/122

Code where this very failure was observed is OpenStack's glance_store drivers, for example
https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/tag/0.29.0/glance_store/_drivers/cinder.py#L676

It seems something like 
```
            if name and name.lower() in ('md4', 'md5'):
```
would suffice to fix it.

items.title: Bandit 1.6.0 no longer respects excluded directories
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

```
bandit -r . -x ./mymodule1/tests/,./mymodule2/tests/
```

items.title: Bandit conflicts with pyflakes
items.body:
Bandit is conflicting with pyflakes when both are used together, due to how the monkeypatching of ast nodes is done by both projects.

The issue was diagnosed on the flake8 bug tracker at https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/536#note_166421843
> Both bandit and pyflakes monkeypatch the ast nodes, then inspect that state later.  In this case, the bandit monkeypatching interferes with pyflakes detection of its own monkeypatching.

Here's the test case provided by @asottile in the flake8 issue:

```
>>> from bandit.core.config import BanditConfig
>>> from bandit.core.meta_ast import BanditMetaAst
>>> from bandit.core.metrics import Metrics
>>> from bandit.core.node_visitor import BanditNodeVisitor
>>> from bandit.core.test_set import BanditTestSet
>>> from pyflakes.checker import Checker
>>> import ast
>>> profile = {}
>>> bnv = BanditNodeVisitor(
...     'filename',
...     BanditMetaAst(),
...     BanditTestSet(BanditConfig(), profile=profile),
...     False,
...     [],
...     Metrics(),
... )
>>> tree = ast.parse("""def test():
...     try:
...         x = 5
...         if True:
...             x = 10  # noqa: F841
...     except AttributeError:
...         pass
... """)
>>> bnv.generic_visit(tree)
>>> Checker(tree=tree)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 673, in __init__
    self.runDeferred(self._deferredFunctions)
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 710, in runDeferred
    handler()
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 1474, in runFunction
    self.handleChildren(node, omit='decorator_list')
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 1073, in handleChildren
    self.handleNode(node, tree)
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 1120, in handleNode
    handler(node)
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 1623, in TRY
    self.handleNode(child, node)
  File "/tmp/t/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyflakes/checker.py", line 1120, in handleNode
```

items.title: "f-string" Interpolation Not Recognized as SQL Injection
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
In Python 3.6, [literal string interpolation](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0498/) was added in the form of "f-strings." Bandit does not seem to recognize interpolation by this method. 

**To Reproduce**
```
# Vulnerable to SQL Injection. Bandit DOES NOT report an issue.

value = 'foo'
cursor.execute(
    'SELECT foo, '
    'bar '
    'FROM foo_table '
    f'WHERE foo = {value};'
)


# Vulnerable to SQL Injection. Bandit DOES report an issue.

value = 'foo'
cursor.execute(
    'SELECT foo, '
    'bar '
    'FROM foo_table '
    'WHERE foo = {value};'.format(value=value)
)
```

**Expected behavior**
"f-string" interpolation should be recognized as a SQL injection vulnerability

**Bandit version**
<!--- Paste the output from "bandit --version" between quotes below -->
```
bandit 1.5.1
  python version = 3.7.0 (default, Sep 18 2018, 18:47:22) [Clang 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)]
```

items.title: Hash and crypto blacklists greatly increasing execution time
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
An update to the hash and crypto blacklists in v1.5.0 has seemed to have a dramatic impact on the execution time. I have tested this across a number of python projects and the execution time is consistently increased by almost an order of magnitude when Bandit is run with tests B303, B304, and B305 enabled. I used an open source project I maintain to demonstrate below. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Spin up a virtualenv and install Bandit v1.4.0
2. Run Bandit with no skips and then with `-s B303,B304,B305`
3. Observe the execution time is roughly equivalent
4. Upgrade Bandit to >=1.5.0
5. Run Bandit twice more, without and with skips
6. Notice the discrepancies between execution times

**Expected behavior**
Output with v1.4.0
```
(venv) $ pip install bandit==1.4.0
Collecting bandit==1.4.0
  ...
  ...
Installing collected packages: bandit
Successfully installed bandit-1.4.0
(venv) $ time bandit -r src/ -f txt -o /dev/null
[main]	INFO	profile include tests: None
[main]	INFO	profile exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli include tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	running on Python 2.7.10
[text]	INFO	Text output written to file: /dev/null

real	0m0.716s
user	0m0.545s
sys	0m0.134s
(venv) $ time bandit -r src/ -s B303,B304,B305 -f txt -o /dev/null
[main]	INFO	profile include tests: None
[main]	INFO	profile exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli include tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli exclude tests: B303,B304,B305
[main]	INFO	running on Python 2.7.10
[text]	INFO	Text output written to file: /dev/null

real	0m0.663s
user	0m0.550s
sys	0m0.106s
```

**Observed behavior**
```
(venv) $ pip install --upgrade bandit
Collecting bandit
  ...
  ...
Installing collected packages: bandit
  Found existing installation: bandit 1.4.0
    Uninstalling bandit-1.4.0:
      Successfully uninstalled bandit-1.4.0
Successfully installed bandit-1.5.1
(venv) $ time bandit -r src/ -f txt -o /dev/null
[main]	INFO	profile include tests: None
[main]	INFO	profile exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli include tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	running on Python 2.7.10
[text]	INFO	Text output written to file: /dev/null

real	0m7.792s
user	0m7.650s
sys	0m0.124s
(venv) $ time bandit -r src/ -s B303,B304,B305 -f txt -o /dev/null
[main]	INFO	profile include tests: None
[main]	INFO	profile exclude tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli include tests: None
[main]	INFO	cli exclude tests: B303,B304,B305
[main]	INFO	running on Python 2.7.10
[text]	INFO	Text output written to file: /dev/null

real	0m0.722s
user	0m0.592s
sys	0m0.117s
```

**Bandit version**
<!--- Paste the output from "bandit --version" between quotes below -->
```
bandit 1.5.1
  python version = 2.7.10 (default, Aug 17 2018, 17:41:52) [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 10.0.0 (clang-1000.0.42)]
```

**Additional context**
While the execution time is still negligible relative to the rest of the test suite for this particular project (it's less than 1000 lines of code), I use Bandit in a production CI/CD pipeline. Bandit scans ~350,000 lines of code and, after upgrading, execution time has increased from ~1m20s to ~9m30s on average when building locally on my machine.

items.title: More specific nosec options

milestone.title: Near Future
milestone.description: Issues that will be addressed in the near future. After the current release milestone but possibly in release+1.

items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I couldn't find any way to specify `# nosec` for a particular bandit issue, which means `# nosec` could accidentally mask multiple issues. I have a contrived example:

```
import yaml
assert yaml.load("{}") == []  # nosec
```

This results in `B101:assert_used` and `B506:yaml_load`. Obviously, it could trivially be split up over several lines, but illustrates the issue how `# nosec` can mask more than one issue. This may have happened over time, for example the assert may have been `assert foo = []` previously, and the load vulnerability was introduced later.

TL;DR: I'd like to be able to suppress just one issue.

Additionally, it would be nice to be able to suppress some issues on a per file/module basis. For most use-cases, `exclude` probably works fine, but again it's either all or nothing. Happy to submit a different feature request for this.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I think pylint does this well. [As stated in their FAQ](http://pylint.pycqa.org/en/latest/faq.html#message-control):

>  4.1 Is it possible to locally disable a particular message?
> [...] by adding "#pylint: disable=some-message,another-one" at the desired block level or at the end of the desired line of code
> 4.2 Is there a way to disable a message for a particular module only?
> Yes [...] at the module level by adding the corresponding option in a comment at the top of the file

flake8 also [offers fine-grained ignores](http://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/violations.html#in-line-ignoring-errors) via e.g. `# noqa: E731`.

For bandit then, it could be something like:

```
assert yaml.load("{}") == []  # nosec: disable=B101
assert yaml.load("{}") == []  # nosec: disable=assert_used
```
or 
```
assert yaml.load("{}") == []  # nosec: B101
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

* Use `nosec` and hope it doesn't mask any issues down the line
* Disable a certain issue globally and hope it doesn't occur anywhere in the codebase

**Additional context**

items.title: Does the PyYaml dependency break Python 3.7 support when using pipenv?
items.body:
Does `PyYaml 3.12` break `bandit`s Python 3.7 support under some circumstances?

The Python 3.7 [`bandit 1.5.1` build log](https://travis-ci.org/PyCQA/bandit/jobs/444436441#L478) states installation of `PyYaml 3.13`.

When I try to create a Python 3.7.0 environment (`bandit==1.5.1`) via `pipenv install --python 3.7.0 ...` I get an error `An error occurred while installing bandit! Will try again.` whose root cause seems to be `PyYaml` (`Failed building wheel for PyYAML`).

According to [`lower-constraints.txt`](https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/blob/1.5.1/lower-constraints.txt#L27) `bandit 1.5.1` depends on `PyYaml==3.12`. The `pipenv` output shows `Collecting PyYAML>=3.12 (from bandit->-r /tmp/pipenv-y2xrl_5w-requirements/pipenv-ds4s1gv8-requirement.txt (line 1))`. The [PyYaml changelog](https://pyyaml.org/wiki/PyYAML) states:

>3.13 (2018-07-05)
>
>    Rebuild wheels using latest Cython for Python 3.7 support.

BTW: Creating a Python 3.6.5 environment (`pipenv install --python 3.6.7 ...`) works fine.

It seems as `bandit` has problems with only three Russian letters `эяс` because when running the `flake8` with the comment containing all Russian letters except `эяс`, it works fine:

```python
# -*- coding: UTF-8 -*-
"""Module docstring."""
print('hello') # йцукенгшщзхъфывапролджё
```

**Expected behavior**
Bandit should handle all Cyrillic characters without throwing `UnicodeDecodeError` error.

**Bandit version**
```
(BanditDebug) C:\Users\user>bandit --version
bandit 1.5.1
  python version = 3.6.6 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Jun 28 2018, 11:21:07) [MSC v.1900 32 bit (Intel)]
```

items.title: What is the way to ignore/skip some issues from report?
items.body: I've got a bunch of `django_mark_safe` errors ``` >> Issue: [B703:django_mark_safe] Potential XSS on mark_safe function. Severity: Medium Confidence: High Location: ... More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b703_django_mark_safe.html 54 return mark_safe(f'{title}') -------------------------------------------------- >> Issue: [B308:blacklist] Use of mark_safe() may expose cross-site scripting vulnerabilities and should be reviewed. Severity: Medium Confidence: High Location: ... More Info: https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/blacklists/blacklist_calls.html#b308-mark-safe 54 return mark_safe(f'{title}') -------------------------------------------------- ``` And I'm curious if there is a way to skip or ignore such lines? I understand that using `mark_safe` could be dangerous, but what if I want to take the risk? For example this method is the only way to display custom link in Django admin, so I don't know any other option how to do it without `mark_safe`

items.title: Docs lack information on baseline function and how to use it
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
The bandit baseline command and function is missing from the docs and README.  This can be a very useful feature and should be properly documented.

items.title: Ignore specific methods for vulnerabilities
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Is it possible to ignore vulnerabilities at a function/method level? I know it's possible to ignore folders and files but would be nicer to be able to ignore/exclude at a finer grain level.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Perhaps a decorator/annotation at the method level to ignore specific vulnerabilities by code.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
We've considered addressing the issue but it would break backwards compatibility. Ex we use MD5 to hash assets which are served. MD5 was deliberately chosen for its speed.

**Additional context**
If it's possible to ignore at the method/function level then perhaps its documentation needs to be made more accessible.

items.title: --quiet and  --silent options, to reduce or eliminate output when passing
items.body:
I run Bandit in CI for a few repos now, and it's been both useful when finding potential issues (and one actual problem - thanks!) and annoyingly verbose when everything is OK.  I just don't want contributors to have to scroll through **27 lines** of output when silence would be fine and the failure is coming from some other tool.

So in the Unix tradition of "silence is golden", I would love a `--quiet` and a `--silent` option to take output away, just as the existing `--verbose` and `--debug` options add more.

items.title: #nosec string outside of a comment is treated as a comment
items.body:
From @ehooo in https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/issues/211#issuecomment-390034850:

> Hi I found a bug related with the way that "nosec " comment is checked.
> For example `vulnerable_call(param="#nosec")` this line will be scaped

When fixing this, please do not introduce a regression that prevents use of in-line `# nosec` comments alongside other source code analyzers' line comment directives? Consider someone who uses Mypy notations, pyflakes, pylint, and bandit:

`…  # type: … # nosec # noqa: E501 ; pylint: disable=line-too-long`

items.title: Bandit flagging pycryptodome as a high vulnerability
items.body:
Hi

Thanks for Bandit!

Having built an old repo, which uses pycryptodome, I've found it now breaks the build, because we fail on `bandit -lll`. This is intentional of course, but I'm struggling to find documentation on specific issues with pycryptodome that would help us understand the risk/urgency of this. If you have links available on this it'd be really helpful, as Googling it mostly gives pages about migrating _to_ pycryptodome :-)

Really appreciate any pointers


Rob

items.title: Investigate automatic release notes generation
items.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The last releases of Bandit do not provide any changelog which makes it difficult for users to estimate the impact (risks and benefits) of updating to newer versions. See our main user-facing portals for new releases:
- PyPI module info: https://pypi.org/project/bandit/1.5.1/#history
- GitHub release notes: https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/releases

**Describe the solution you'd like**
To reduce the burden on maintainers, investigate ways to generate changelogs automatically from the commit or PR history and to push this information to GitHub release notes and PyPI.

Possible solutions:
- GitHub release drafter plugin: https://github.com/apps/release-drafter
- custom script? Travis job?
- python package: https://pypi.org/project/gitchangelog/

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
There is a releasenotes folder in the source tree (https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/tree/master/releasenotes) though it doesn't seem to be used and provide the level of automation we are aiming for.

items.title: Paramiko injection test not testing SSHClient.invoke_shell() properly
items.body:
While working on #374, I noticed that the [paramiko injection test](https://github.com/PyCQA/bandit/blob/master/examples/paramiko_injection.py#L10) is not actually testing `SSHClient.invoke_shell()` because it can't resolve `SSHClient` and the function call is wrong.

Should be:
```
import paramiko

ssh_client = paramiko.client.SSHClient()
ssh_client.invoke_shell()
```

Instead of:
```
import paramiko

SSHClient.invoke_shell('something; bad; here\n')
```

**Expected behavior**
Bandit should flag `SSHClient.invoke_shell()` correctly.

**Bandit version**
```
1.5.0
```

 ```
    except Exception as ex:
```

Unused variable with-in nested try/except blocks should also be captured.

bandit                        1.4.0 [ Centos 7 ]

```
```

Add any other context about the problem here.

Not sure what should happen here: set to empty string, so that it never matches the problematic imports? Or add a mechanism that recognises this type of dynamic import and raises a warning, since this could be used to load a problematic module? I'm leaning towards the second.


**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Add a dynamically resolved import to your code; see above description for example code.
2. Run bandit against that code.
3. Observe the drawing of the "progress bar" being interrupted with a stacktrace.

**Expected behavior**
This style of importing should probably be treated as potentially dangerous, and be added to the report as such. It should not display a stacktrace on the console.

**Bandit version**
<!--- Paste the output from "bandit --version" between quotes below -->
```
bandit 1.4.1
  python version = 2.7.14 (default, Sep 23 2017, 22:06:14) [GCC 7.2.0]
```

**Additional context**
Tested on the latest commit at the time of writing: 0d9551c

items.title: Update project info on, and upload new versions to PyPy
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm ignoring the template in this case since it's not really a bug, nor is it a feature request.

The installation instructions instruct us to `pip install bandit`, since [bandit is on PyPi](https://pypi.org/project/bandit/#description). However, the version on PyPi is woefully out of date: as of now it points to v1.4.0, which was uploaded to PyPi 20 months ago.

- This means we're unable to benefit from the improvements that have since been made, such as the more_info url in the json output.
- Furthermore, that page still links to the old OpenStack pages for the documentation and code, and to Launchpad for the issue tracker.

items.title: Consider removing PyCryptodome from blacklist
items.body:
As the maintainer of PyCryptodome, I have reservations on the library being blacklisted (B414).

Can you help me understand why you think it "*has not fully addressed the issues inherent in PyCrypto*"?

It shares none of the bugs, and it broke API compatibility with it by dropping the most dangerous ones (such as having ECB as the default cipher mode).

You can certainly shoot yourself in the foot with the low-level primitives, but the same can be achieved with `cryptography` (which is a great project, no doubts about it).

items.title: Codes B301-B306 conflict with flake8-bugbear
items.body:
This is related to a discussion ongoing in the flake8-bugbear repo issues: https://github.com/PyCQA/flake8-bugbear 

Main points pasted below from @myii on Github: 

```
The conflict is not with flake8-bandit but rather with openstack/bandit

There are two projects that are involved here:

    https://github.com/openstack/bandit
        Project started on 16 July 2014
        This is the main project, where the conflicts are arising

    https://github.com/tylerwince/flake8-bandit
        Project started on 29 Oct 2017
        However, this is just a wrapper around bandit
        They have no control over the error codes that are supplied by bandit

The OpenStack Bandit project has been using B30x codes for a few years as well

Taking B301 as the earliest example in both projects:

    Bandit: openstack/bandit@c364408
        This commit was made on 22 Jan 2016

    Bugbear: 0fb7d8d
        This commit was made on 8 Jun 2016
```

items.title: bandit hangs if current directory contains __init__.py
items.body:
Hi!

The function bandit.core.utils.get_module_qualname_from_path() examines the filepath from right-to-left looking for a directory without an __init__.py. If bandit is called using relative paths inside a directory that contains a __init__.py, this function enters an infinite loop.

Example:

```
.:
__init__.py  test/

./test:
__init__.py  test.py
```

Calling bandit with `bandit test/test.py` leads to an infinite loop. `bandit ./test/test.py` gives the expected result (with detected qualname `test.test`).

The following diff to get_module_qualname_from_path() appears to fix the issue:

```
-     while head not in ['/', '.']:
+     while head not in ['/', '.', '']:
```

Thanks

items.title: Make 'target' arg optional and let it be defined in the ini file
items.body:
settings that are read by bandit from ini files are already almost complete for most projects (excludes, tests and skips) but are missing 'target' that must be always specified explicitly.

Adding it to CLI arguments that could be read from ini file would ease bandit configuration as we could store its ini settings in the tox.ini itself (almost like flake8 allows) and run it as "bandit --ini tox.ini"

Later we could add autodetection of bandit section in the tox.ini too.

items.title: Exit code should be 0 for successful program completion
items.body:
https://github.com/openstack/bandit/blob/master/bandit/cli/main.py#L346

Bandit should always return zero upon successful program completion. If a non-zero exit code is returned, it indicates an unsuccessful program completion in a general sense.

items.title: Comma separated exclude paths not honored
items.body:
in a .bandit file, setting multiple exclude: paths doesn't work

[bandit]
exclude: /src/tests,/src/docs


This will exclude the /src/tests directory, but not the /src/docs dir.

Including multiple exclude lines has 'last one wins'

[bandit]
exclude: /src/tests
exclude: /src/docs

This will exclude the /src/docs directory, but not /src/tests

items.title: Check for PyCryptodome and PyCryptodomex in weak key plugin
items.body:
With PyCrypto unmaintained, hostile forks are present - the most prominent of which is PyCryptodome (https://github.com/Legrandin/pycryptodome).

This project has two installable PyPI targets:

- PyCryptodome
- PyCryptodomex

The former provides a drop in replacement for PyCrytpo so we should be able to catch imports using the existing plugin (import Crypto).

The latter provides a different module: Cryptodome which provides similar functionality but under a new name. This should be added to the weak key check.

An example of a safe way to escape is selectively for html and xss:

env = Environment(
    loader=PackageLoader('yourapplication', 'templates'),
    autoescape=select_autoescape(['html', 'xml'])
)

We should update the Bandit plugin to not flag people following the Jinja directions.

items.title: XSS in HTML report output
items.body:
The following Python code snippet will cause script execution when a HTML report is generated and viewed:

import subprocess
subprocess.Popen("<script>alert(1)</script>", shell=True)


This is because the HTML formatter is failing to HTML escape the code snippets.  We need to investigate the best standard library (or OpenStack condoned library) to HTML escape and then apply that to the issue text.

items.title: Disable terminal formatting codes when shell is not interactive
items.body:
When the shell environment is not interactive (e.g., bandit is piped to `less`), then terminal formatting codes, such as colors, should be disabled. Otherwise, the output to less and other command line programs becomes really messy.

To implement this enhancement, add a check like `istty()` before enabling terminal formatting codes.

We should add a quick section that describes how to make this work.
